column1: '''''Epic Pooh''''' is an article by the British science fiction writer Michael Moorcock
column3: and revised for inclusion in his 1987 book ''[[Wizardry and Wild Romance]]''. In it
column4: Moorcock reviews the field of epic fantasy
column5: with a particular focus on epic fantasy written for children. The article has proven controversial because of its attack on [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.

column1: Moorcock criticises a group of celebrated writers of epic fantasy for children
column4: and Richard Adams. His criticism is based on two principles: the poverty of their writing style
column5: and a political criticism. Moorcock accuses these authors of espousing a form of "corrupted Romance"
column6: which he identifies with Anglican Toryism. The defining traits of this attitude are an anti-technological
column7: anti-urban stance which is ultimately misanthropic
column8: that glorifies a vanished or vanishing rural idyll
column9: and is rooted in middle-class or bourgeois attitudes towards progress and political change.
